awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: How Perceptions of Social Difference Influence International Engagements
awd_abstract_narration:
How do markers of social difference such as race, nationality, and identity interact to affect approaches to foreign policy? This is a longstanding question in the social sciences whose answers inform our understanding of what promotes versus constrains diplomatic versus hostile relationships at multiple levels of interaction. This doctoral dissertation project investigates the ways that perceptions of social difference intersect to inform interactions among individuals working in international relations. In addition to training a U.S.-based graduate student in scientific cultural anthropology, the work promotes participation of under-represented minorities in science and distributes its findings broadly to academic and non-academic audiences. 

The project leverages recent changes in how international diplomacy is conducted by members of under-represented minorities to ask whether and how race, nationality, and identity interact to affect approaches to foreign policy. The student investigator conducts participant observation among career diplomats, foreign relations experts, and other stakeholders to understand the day-to-day means by which identity factors inform policy understandings, development, and implementation. The researcher complements this activity with interviews and media analysis to place insights within broader contexts of dynamic international politics. The project provides insights regarding how various aspects of identity intersect to affect relationships among individuals and the extension of these to international diplomacy, adding nuance to theories that have considered identity in a more compartmentalized fashion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This study expands diplomatic scholarship through an ethnography of current and former career diplomats at the Department of State (DOS), looking specifically at how race, identity, and nationality impact interactions in US foreign policy. Over the course of 15 months of fieldwork in Washington, DC, the Co-Principal Investigator successfully interviewed and engaged with approximately 100 international policy professionals in academia, government, non-profit, think-tank, and media organizations. These engagements revealed 1) a well-defined foreign policy expert community marked by racial, gender, and class inequality, 2) professional alliances informed by race which influenced foreign policymaking at multiple levels of interaction, and 3) how diplomatic statecraft both draws on perceptions of social difference and engenders newfound discussions on the role of identity in international politics.

 

The Co-PI established meetings and interviews with foreign policy scholars, government officials, diplomats, students, and activists in the DC, Maryland, and Virginia (DMV) area. The Co-PI also developed working relationships with historians and staff at the National Museum of American Diplomacy, the Office of the Historian at DOS, Ralph J. Bunche International Affairs Center, and the Moorland Spingarn Research Center at Howard University. Furthermore, the Co-PI was able to expand the research participant base through engagement with prominent professional organizations in the DMV. Due to fluctuating changes with the COVID-19 pandemic, the Co-PI used digital tools for interviewing and observation, such as zoom video calls, phone conversations, chat groups and virtual events. During this time, the Co-PI also tracked social media usage amongst research participants to show ways in which identity, diplomacy, and race are linked for international actors on digital platforms. Data collection also included content and media analysis of government reports and archival material, such as photographs, newspaper articles, oral history interviews, and maps, at the Library of Congress and the Congressional Research Service. In February 2023, the Co-PI received a no-cost extension to continue data collection for an additional four months and used findings to complete a doctoral dissertation in June 2024.

 

This project provides preliminary evidence that perceptions of social difference, particularly race, inform diplomatic engagements at multiple levels. Diplomats from underrepresented racial groups in the United States mobilize their intersectional identities to shape policy and promote international partnerships with non-traditional foreign policy actors. This study demonstrates the integral roles of race and identity in foreign policymaking and furthers critical scholarship on the experience of minorities in government. Its framework also encourages future research and exploration into the ways in which other identity markers, such as gender, class, ableness, etc., inform the policymaking process and diplomacy. Research in this area expands social science understandings of the linkages between race and diplomacy and analyzes how sociohistorical and cultural perceptions of difference and marginalization impact international politics and transnational partnerships.
